text: The fact that we refer to it now as "Climate Change" instead of "Global Warming" like we used to is part of the problem too. See, Global Warming sounds dangerous...because it is and that is an accurate way to describe the situation. Climate Change sounds very neutral. It's not inherently negative or positive. Is the climate changing for the better or the worse? It doesn't say. Republicans, however, pushed to popularize the term "Climate Change" over "Global Warming" for that reason, so that people wouldn't feel quite as scared and motivated to stop it, so that they can keep taking fossil fuel money or something else that they overrate to an absurd degree. So let's call this what it is, it's Global Warming, and it's very scary and dangerous (Global Weirding is also alright, because it does make our weather and climate act weird)!

text:
¬†@waiotahi52¬† Thanks for seeing past my irascible putdown (for which I apologise) and asking a genuine question.
The flaw with your premise (as I see it) is that it's a trivial truism, which is not susceptible as a starting point for any useful train of reasoning.
You could (for instance) use similar reasoning to try to invalidate a warning about an impending change in sea level (perhaps arising from an unprecendented circumstance, like an undersea landslide) by observing that the sea level is constantly changing (due to tides, changes in atmospheric pressure distribution, or whatever).
Your argument can be summed up as "everything changes", which is true but not useful.
There is no precedent for what happens when billions of years' worth of accumulated carbon, from lifeforms, is released into the atmosphere in a mere couple of centuries, and your "reasoning" does not in any way illuminate the implications, nor does it seem to me to provide a sound foundation for not caring about them.

text:
I hate to say it, but it comes down to a lack of understanding the science, and a negative reaction to media panic, bad emphasis on what to worry about for it, and the fact us Americans just don't understand the concept of science on any real level to begin with.
Let's be honest: When's the last time someone here read an actual scientific paper? Abstract, Methods, Data, Conclusions, what have you. Most people I know have never read one, and hence understanding this crap comes down to word of mouth instead of true understanding. Someone explains the concepts in abstract, sure, but if you just take their word for it, you become the parallel to guys watching Rush talk on the radio about this shit back in the day.

So, when we talk about climate change, and a lot of people don't understand that they can literally pop open any paper on the topic and read it transparently, or have all the relevant factors explained to them (for instance, people routinely fall for false stories about the sun or other forms of orbital forcing) so they can truly understand it. It becomes a political "he said" "she said" situation, instead of actually trying to educate ourselves.

A great example is in this video right here, ironically, since both left and right media fuck up on the topic fairly regularly, although the american right wing very much moreso. The guy mentions the ice caps melting, which is actually nothing of true value. Even after hitting the fatal point of CO2 levels, it'd take hundreds upon hundreds of years for the ice caps to completely melt, and what it would actually swallow isn't that noteworthy. We're currently seeing a matter of millimeters of sea rise per year at the minute, and while that will accelerate, it's still symptomatic of sea level rise and ice cap melt not being the true problem... But they are still problems, that's just not why.

Sea ice melting will de-salinate the oceans, for instance, in addition to lowering albedo (how much sunlight the surface of the earth reflects, like a guy in a white t-shirt standing outside on a hot day), which will most notably contribute to "positive feedback", wherein some warming helps speed up or contribute to more warming. That right there is a serious problem. Polar bear numbers are sketchy on whether they're up and down, due to being hard to monitor with confidence, but acidification of bodies of water will cause massive damage to amphibians, who reproduce in water regularly. More intense heat will give reptiles less time to mate and find food, for fear of dying of heat stroke (the flip side of being cold blooded in action), and melting open sinkholes out in Siberia and other places will release shittons of methane. While CO2 is certainly not something you want to throw out willy-nilly, methane has 20 fold the warming power of CO2, meaning that shit's gonna really help fuck things up if we can't ground our act. Droughts, fires, desync between pollinators and plants, shifts in cold weather due to changes in the gulf streams and the polar vortex... There's lots of shit to be worried about... But just saying "sea levels", "ice caps", or "polar bears" is a meaningless without properly conveying an understanding of why a lot of that shit is symoptomatic of a much bigger, deadlier picture.

Damn near none of the developed world is stupid enough to not comprehend the science properly... At least consistently. We here in America hold a monopoly on being climate science illiterate on a truly political scale, and quite frankly that's what's holding the world back. What is arguably the current world power is too fucking stupid to understand there's a problem, let alone that both left wing and right wing solutions exist to the problem. We've spent so much time denying climate problems on the right that we don't even think about trying to motivate the free market into pulling a lot of the weight for technological advancement that needs to be done on renewable energy sources. Which side has more value is entirely up in the air, but the least we in America could do is have a real, full conversation on the topic instead of trying to educate a swarm of 30 to 50 year olds with the brain of a 7 year old. That's just fucking sad.

text:
Honestly a lot of us can't afford to take the alternative options that are better for our environment. Add on that the majority of the problem is major corporations and a failure to properly regulate the system, there isn't a lot the majority of people can do. Our focus is on surviving, and a lot of us can't afford to do more than that. People say "just go vegan" like it isn't expensive to eat a proper vegan diet, and much more expensive than a lot of options for people to feed themselves. A lot of us care, but feel like there isn't much we can actually do. Repeatedly being shown that our votes don't matter in a lot of areas (gerrymandering/etc), repeatedly being shown that even if a candidate has shown a history of supporting regulation/preventative measures for the issues they get into office and either hit roadblocks (republicans/corporations) or just fail to live up to the expectation they created, repeatedly being shown that even if we care on an individual level everything above us doesn't. There's a lot of things we want to do, but right now it's very difficult if not impossible for a lot of people. Some cities have it right, increasing recycling efforts and providing more resources for people to be able to do the right thing. Other cities act like they don't care at all. 


Most products that actually have companies who care are 30-50% more expensive than the general products we buy, which makes it inaccessible to the majority of people. Fair trade/sustainable/green/eco friendly/etc products are definitely something we should be aiming for, but when they are so expensive it's something most people won't be able to do, or won't be willing to do because it would limit what options they have for buying other products. We need stronger regulations on businesses/corporations, and we need to look at who the highest contributors are (china/india/etc). We can do a lot to try and change, but if other countries don't follow suit it's basically asking for people to potentially put themselves into financial hardships for absolutely nothing. There are a lot of things individuals can do, but the majority of it needs to come from the top down. Lobbyists lining politicians pockets are one of our biggest problems, just look at what's happening with the coal industry and other environmental improvement rollbacks. 


We care, but it feels like it's a hopeless battle with no positive ending. We care, but it feels like we are ultimately powerless to stop the problems, even if we do all the right things. We care, but ditching plastic bags for reusable ones isn't going to do anything in the big picture without regulation and city wide changes. If everyone had enough money to be able to do the right thing, maybe things would be a little different. But for the most part at the end of the day, the average person really can't afford to care.

text: We should wait for the government to fix it.  That logic is also a great way to defer personal responsibility and any sacrifice; to hold on the to the excess.  Bravo.  Instead of relying on someone else (or top down) why not start from the bottom up.  Lifestyle is a learned behavior and daily choice.  Leaving your car idling for no reason is a choice.  Using 1000 plastic grocery bags every year is a choice.  Policy is for people that don't know better.  If you know better, you have no excuse.  None of this rationalized avoidance bullshit.  Take action.  Stop having individual items overnighted to your house from amazon (make a list order in bulk and BE PATIENT).  How many tons of fuel would get saved simply buy ordering less or buying locally (merchandise that relies on trucks).  Make your Vote count and go and do it,  reduce the amount of stuff you buy, reuse stuff and as a last resort recycle stuff.  Don't buy excess just because it can be "recycled" because depending on where and how this process happens it might end up in the dump or a furnace.  Look in the mirror and tell yourself there's nothing you can do... or is there?  Do your best.  By changing your actions you will internalize the importance of climate change and get out the door on election day.  The solution doesn't begin with top down action because the solution can't gain public support without people who practice and understand conservation and that begins with you.  Make it an apolitical decision.  This is no time for party allegiance.

text:
‚Äã¬†@Raptor Shadow Suit¬† 0.3 billion tonnes of fuel will be burned in 2019 by airplanes, or 300 Mtoe of energy (million tonnes of oil equivalent) which is 12560400 terajoules.
90 terajoules is equivalent to a gramme of matter, (from E=mc^2) so the combustion of that amount of fuel will deplete the input side of the process (the fuel + the atmosphere) by 12560400/90=139,560g or 140 kg.
The mass balance for combustion is about 10 cu m of air per litre of fuel
10 cu m of air weighs 13 kg and a litre of fuel weighs 0.8kg, so the mass balance is 10/0.8=16.3 units of atmospheric weight per unit of fuel burned. So the mass lost to the atmosphere in 2019 from jet travel will be 16.3/17.3*140=  132 kg "dissipated", in your language.
That's about the combined weight of a well-fed married couple, in countries which do not have McDonalds and do not drink Coke.
It's more than I expected, frankly, but hardly cause for alarm. You may put your mind at rest.

text: When i was a kid the news insisted that the polar ice caps would melt and flood the entire planet by the year 2000. Which is entirely unrealistic for a number of reasons. Not the least of which being that the polar ice caps dont contain anywhere close to the amount of water required to cause the "waterworld" scenario. The fact is that climate change alarmism has been the trendy apocalyptic fantasy scenario ever since it replace the religious apocalypse fantasy a few decades ago. Soon it will phase out in favor of the increasingly popular artificial intelligence apocalypse fantasy. That will be replaced by some other silly theory and so on and so forth. There are only 2 realistic threats to life on this planet in the next few million years, asteroid impact and nuclear war. This planet has gone thru countless warming and cooling cycles in its 4 billion years and will continue for billions more. In fact warmer periods are more compatible with more forms of life than cooler ones according to the fossil record. In short climate change alarmism is BS always has been, always will be.

text:
There's also the fact that we just aren't MADE to care for all of humanity. We logically understand that it's bad when other people are in danger or face hardship or die, but aside from some diffuse empathy, our brain is mainly understanding threats to our own "tribe" aka family/region/nationality/wherever you draw the line.

Almost everyone understands that it is bad when polar bears raid apartment complexes and islands sink into the ocean and thousands of people lose their homes to wildfires, but unless you are directly affected, how much do you actually care? Are you willing to change your entire way of life every single day for total strangers? Sure, the moment you hear about something bad happening you feel bad too, maybe even to the point to be compelled to act. But are you gonna think of someone in the Philippines possibly losing their house to flooding everyday of your life and, for example, take the bike over the car even when it's inconvenient for them? That's just not how humans work. 

I think thanks to the globalized world we live in nowadays, we often have family and friendships all over the world, so everyone's personal "tribe" is no longer bound by location, meaning we are more likely to worry about issues in other regions of the world more seriously now. Also, more and more people are straightup feeling the effects themselves too, making them realize the threat as quite real. So I think we are on a good way, teaching our caveman brain one step at a time ;)

text:
YO IVE BEEN LIVING SUSTAINABLY FOR A YEAR AND A HALF. It helps living in the city but still. I‚Äôve also developed an app to help people seamlessly and accurately track their carbon footprint and compare their emissions to sustainable benchmarks. It breaks your emissions profile down temporally into different emissions sectors (eg transportation, residential energy etc) and, in so doing, helps you strategize ways to reduce your footprint. requires the user to do minimal input (eg occasionally log information from your power bill, or input odometer info - unless you turn on the automated drive tracking feature). There is so much more to it but I‚Äôll spare the synopsis. I‚Äôm just excited about it. It‚Äôs called footprint and is fully patented and trademarked which is why I‚Äôm not worried about disclosing. 
Here‚Äôs the thing climate change can only be solved through the full scale mobilization of the private sector as well as governments on local, state/provincial, national, and international scales so this HAS TO BE AN ISSUE IN THE VOTING BOOTH. We cannot solve this through the good intentions of the people that care most about it. There has to be laws and policies that reform markets and the economy as well as generation infrastructure. AT THE SAME TIME we are all part of the problem so we all have to be part of the solution. The time to act on climate change was yesterday so there‚Äôs literally no such thing as doing too much too soon. Whatever you‚Äôre doing isn‚Äôt enough. Yea, YOU! So the goal of my app is two fold. It‚Äôs a source of catharsis for people who, like me, loose sleep over the fact they feel like they‚Äôre not doing  everything they can. But also it raises the awareness of climate change in the conciounce if people who use the app as well as identifies systemic barriers unique to their circumstances and area to achieving a sustainable footprint. These barriers could be considered public priorities for climate action. So the app could possibly help mobilize. Irregardless whatever you do will just be a small drop in a vast ocean. But a million drops creates a tidal wave of change. My only regret is putting this app in the back burner for so long.
The desktop version which runs on excel is fully up and running. Now we are programming it for iOS and android devices. Stay tuned.

text:
I've been saying for almost 20 years, ask any vineyard owner in the Central Valley of California what they think of global warming.  It's happening and it's hitting the vineyards and orchards of the Central Valley especially hard.  It's getting too hot to grow certain grapes.  I can smell global warming in the wine because I can smell when a winery is crushing more raisins than grapes.  The wine from California is beginning to reek of raisins.  


The worst part about this is you can't just plow under the vineyard and switch to a different more heat tolerant varietal because it takes years and decades to establish the new root stalks.  My expertise in in wine, but I'm sure it's similar with fruit and nut orchards as well.  Also it's only a matter of time before it starts to effect hop vines as well.  So beer drinkers aren't safe either.  


In conclusion, if you like wine, beer, coffee, chocolate, nutella, fish, maple syrup, cheap (cotton) clothing, be aware that those are going to be the first ones hit.  And I'm only scratching the surface.

text: When people think of climate change, they think it's going to be a bunch of small stuff like no more coffee or chocolate or a few feet of sea level rise.  In reality, they will need a gas mask to go outside, they will die from summertime power black outs to heat stroke, die from actual starvation due to lack of food, die from poisoned water when municipal water supplies are contaminated with overflows of sewage/deadly algae, die from new/migrating diseases, die from plumes of deadly gas from rotting masses of nearby dead animals, die from inability to travel on destroyed roads to get to hospitals, die because their closest hospital was destroyed in an extreme weather event, die directly from an extreme weather event. This is what we can expect as increasingly "normal" starting around 2030 and beyond.  By 2050, these kinds of deaths will be so common they will outpace other leading causes of death as society itself collapses around us. By 2100, there may be no one left alive because weather will have destroyed nearly all major cities and war, famine, and exposure will likely kill the rest.  The daily hassles, expenses, and shortfalls that don't quite add up to "death" will be a part of the miserable life everyone will suffer and are too much to enumerate in a single post.  Maybe we need to put this in movie format, so people realize what a climate holocaust actually looks like?

‚Äî Mark Twain, https://bennorton.com/mark-twain-the-anti-imperialist-anti-capitalist/

"In Civil War era America, slavery was deeply interwoven into Southern society.  There were large sectors of the American economy (including the entire textile industry) that depended on slavery.  Historian Adam Goodheart says that many Americans ‚Äúfelt a sense of guilt, felt a sense of shame" because they "knew that the slave system was wrong but were simply addicted to slavery and couldn't give it up."  He compares it to America's foot-dragging on climate change and how fossil fuels are similarly deeply interwoven into the American economy.  ‚Äú[M]any of us,‚Äù Goodheart says, ‚Äúrecognize that in burning fossil fuels we're doing something terrible for the planet.  We're doing something terrible for future generations. Yet ‚Äúwe continue somewhat guiltily to participate in the system.‚Äù  
‚Äî NPR 2011, ‚ÄúLooking At The Civil War 150 Years Later,‚Äù NPR Fresh Air from WHYY, April 12, 2011, 11:32 AM)  Listen to this Interview of Adam Goodheart by Terry Gross.  https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=135246259 or https://www.npr.org/2011/04/12/135246259/looking-at-the-civil-war-150-years-later

author: Master Exploder

text:
¬†@Master Exploder¬† granted, but if you think our atmospheric carbon is going from 0.5% to anywhere near 30% you are crazy...it will happen slow enough for natural selection as natural history and fossil records show...
As for rising sea levels, well that has always happened and as a matter of fact, a lot of the drivers are out of our control; such as erosion and tectonic plate rebounding and undersea volcanoes. Centuries before the industrial revolution the Netherlands "sunk" quite a bit since Roman times and before - you can look at a Roman map and see for yourself! There will be time to rebuild/relocate infrastructure and habitation on the coasts. Furthermore, even in the unlikely scenario equatorial regions become less habitable, that would mean that conversely higher and lower latitudes would become more habitable.
Also, the two largest contributors to greenhouse gases are not anthropocentric either; #1 by far being plate tectonics releasing trapped gases in the crust...the fracking is the controlled extraction of such gases and #2 being livestock and animals.
Truth be told, unless we can find a way to live off this planet, we are doomed as a species anyway.
author: Ibn Yahud

text: ¬†@Ibn Yahud¬† Not at all true. Humans emit many, many more times CO2 than volcanoes (and all tectonic activity combined). Most of that is for electricity generation and transportation. Livestock and animals are not net emitters of CO2. They get all of their carbon from eating modern plants. This information is not a secret. Climate change is all us, my man. And the predictions aren't usually as good as you say.
author: Master Exploder

text: The difference is that those 2 degrees would naturally take thousands of years, but this time it took a mere couple hundred (since the start of the industrial age specifically).

text: Certain big corporations aren't, but others are. Big Oil and Coal aren't, but other Fortune 500 companies are. Think about certain food corporations that sell coffee, chocolate, seafood, etc. They know impacts from climate change (such as increased droughts, fires, and sea level rise) will negatively impact their bottom line by impacting the plants and animals they use for their products. That is also why many companies are moving towards sustainable water use. But obviously there are other companies that want to ignore climate change all together (airline industry, parts of the agricultural industry, etc.).  This is for biodiversity, but here an interesting talk on how NGOs are making corporations care about the environment: https://www.ted.com/talks/jason_clay_how_big_brands_can_save_biodiversity

text: "Something like 80% of the world's pollution comes from only a handful of large companies." That is not how it works. Those companies produce products for the other 99% of the world population. So it isn't really the fault of only a few big, greedy, corrupt companies. It is the whole of humanity that consumes too much and does not think properly about the repercussions. One example is paper vs plastic bags in Germany (maybe the whole of the EU): normal plastic bags are always being discussed and portraited as sort of the evil thing that kills the environment. Because of that most super markets started introducing the "eco alternative" = paper bags. They are more expensive, more prone to failure (I have bought two and both ripped during the first use, filled with stuff that the old plastic bags would work for 10 times and more) and more energy consuming that the old plastic bags, especially since the plastic bags could be used dozens of times in my experience and then could double up as a trash bag.  The alternative a lot of markets use are sturdy plastic bags (for Americans: they are similar to those blue Ikea bags) or wool/textile bags. Both of those are pretty good from an energy standpoint, the plastic one a bit better than the textile one usually, especially if you use them for years. But the thing is, many people don't plan very well. So they buy a new "one-time-use" bag at the grocery store each time they go shopping. And most of those are now paper, which is the cheapest one. So instead of buying a good plastic one for 1.25‚Ç¨ once and using it for years, they buy a 0.25‚Ç¨ paper bag every week and contribute a lot more to ruining the environment, even though they might think they do the right thing. So people are the problem, not the top companies. And the only way to make everyone take it seriously is to go after the wallet in smart ways and not ways that just "feel good/right", like the paper bags do. We need CO2 taxation, we need to force renewable energy and not listen to those "not in my back yard" idiots that are all around us. We need a smart grid, investment in R&D, government funding and regulated companies in important sectors (energy, distribution, infrastructure, pharmaceutical, farming, food processing etc.).

text:
From 1978 to 1998 the global avg temp of earth increased suddenly by 0.4 degrees C... and then the warming stopped.  The IPCC can't explain the 'pause', and their models do not predict the observed temperatures of the last 40 years, and their warnings are based on the models.  The IPCC is engaged in climate speculation.

"Global Warming" was rebranded "Climate Change"...  because the climate has been changing every moment of every day for billions of years, in extreme ways, and always will.

The correlation between CO2 and temperature seemed promising from 1978 to 1998, but historically its transient at best.  The Roman Warm Period (250BC-400AD) and Medieval Warm Period (950AD-1250AD) both occurred during periods of lower levels of CO2, and well before humans began harnessing and burning hydrocarbons to enhance their lives.

The global warming theories fell apart by 2006,  but investment in the $climate $industry that began with tax payer funding has continued to grow on a massive scale.
https://www.tesla.com/models.

CO2 occurs naturally and is emitted continually by oceans (70% of the surface of the planet), volcanoes, decaying plant life, and breathing animals.  Each human adds about 800 pounds of CO2 into the atmosphere each year just by breathing.

CO2 has a well known property where it's greenhouse effect rapidly diminishes as more is added to the atmosphere.  The next molecule of CO2 has less heat retention qualities than the previous.

CO2 is a minuscule part of the atmosphere.  Only 4 molecules out of every ten thousand molecules of atmosphere are CO2.  150 years ago, before human industrialization, it was 3 out of ten thousand.  In other words, after 150 years of hydrocarbon (fossil) fueled industrialization, plus all the CO2 emitted naturally, there is one extra CO2 molecule out of every ten thousand.

CO2 is essential for life, its not a pollutant.  If the level dropped below 1.5 CO2 molecules per ten thousand atmosphere, plant life would struggle to survive.  In fact more CO2 might be a blessing in the fight against world hunger... CO2 is plant food.

The current level of CO2 is 400ppm (parts per million, or 4 parts per ten thousand).  NASA considers a space station safe with levels up to 3000ppm to 5000ppm.  Submarines are considered safe up to 5000ppm to 8000ppm.

Arctic ice is melting, but only represents 1% of the planet's ice.  The Antarctic and Greenland hold the other 99%  (90% and 9% respectively), and both have seen their ice increase significantly over the course of the last 100 years.  They build research centers in the Antarctic on jacks so they can raise them up each year to keep up with the ice/snow accumulation.  Here's a story about a plane (Glacier Girl) that made an emergency landing on Greenland in 1942 and was discovered under 270 feet of ice in 1992... after 50 years of post war hydrocarbon fueled industrialization.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glacier_Girl

We could go on and on, but basically the planet stopped warming (and only warmed during a blink of an eye 20 year period),  the climate models don't predict observed climate, the climate warnings are based on the models, and there is a great deal of historical evidence of warmer periods with lower levels of CO2 well before humans began burning hydrocarbons.

It's all a bunch of speculation.  In the early seventies, scientists were speculating on the coming Ice Age.


Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas by far.


The earth's massive water system and the Sun likely play far more significant roles in the natural variability of climate.  The idea that the tiny bit of CO2 in the atmosphere as the 'primary forcing agent' driving temperature and climate is simply not supported by objective science.  Not even close.

To be sure, the $climate $industry is $massive. The banks trade $trillions of $dollars of carbon futures every year. Those banks donate $hundreds of $millions to the cause.  It's great for Tesla shareholders, and of course Al Gore made a fortune promoting it.  The $climate $industry is generating a great deal of wealth.

It's also uncaring. The cost of energy drives the cost of food, clothing, housing (protection from climate), healthcare, transportation, education and every other aspect of modern life.

The regressive climate policies and carbon taxes of the rich continue to keep the 2 to 3 Billion of the poorest people on the planet the poorest people on the planet.  They are poor because the most basic form of wealth is access to energy.  It is energy that has allowed humans to thrive.

1 to 1.5 billion only have access to biomass energy (wood, cow dung), and another 1 to 1.5 billion have no regular access to energy... in total roughly 8 times the population of the United States.

If you don't believe any of this, that's wonderful, you're a skeptic.  Do the research, its at your fingertips.  If you haven't looked into the facts yet you believe, that's faith not science.

text:
¬†@J C¬† You are confusing weather with climate. Weather is what exactly is happening each day, and that always changes of course. Local climate is basically the likelihood of certain temperatures, weather phenomenons, etc. occuring in that region.

For example, you can have the specific weather "snow" in the Sahara, but the regional climate there makes it a very rare, unlikely weather condition to occur because the basic conditions in terms of temperature, wind, oceanic streams, etc. are not very likely to lead to snow. 

What climate change does is that it heats up the base temperature of earth (global climate), even in regions that are normally cold (specifically the poles). It's not much, but that BIT of difference is enough to throw massive systems that are the cause of regional climates completely out of whack (for example, the jetstream, the north atlantic gyre, etc.). 

That leads to rare, extreme weather conditions, that USED TO only happen on very rare occasions, to happen very frequently now because the basic systems that create our climates don't work properly anymore.

So for example, a cool area, that used to rarely get a hot spell before - aside from short, occasional highs or lows that happened to move some warmer air from southern regions further north (weather) - may now have constant, neverending heat because the jetstream is going straight-up south-north now instead of west-east and constantly shoving massive amounts of heat to the northern region (changed regional climate) which may be alleviated or strengthened from time to time by the weather, but overall the region is now consistently much hotter, yet neither the plants nor the animals or lifestyle of the people in the region are fit to deal with that.

Ofc that was just one of many examples, your specific region doesn't necessarily need to become hotter, it could get colder too, or drier, or more wet, or a new tornado corridor could form, and so on and so on. 

All of that has nothing to do with the daily weather. The base conditions for each region are getting all f*cked up because we are raising the overall temperature of the planet's atmosphere.

So yes. There have always been floods, droughts, unusually warm winters, severe thunderstorms and whatnot. But what used to happen once every onehundred or onethousand years with this level of severity is now a yearly occurrence because the base conditions have changed.
So no. THIS has NOT always happened.

And that's not even mentioning the direct effects of a higher global temperature, like the rising sea levels for example.

TL;DR
Changing global climate messes up the systems that produce regional climates, which affect how likely different kinds of weather are for that region.

That's not how chaos works.
The butterfly effect refers to the phenomenon when even a slight deviation in the initial conditions can have drastically different consequences. We have no way of knowing whether the consequence will be for 'good' or  'bad'.
So ironically, planting a tree might very well be the single tilting point that pushes us towards the end of days scenario.

text:
That's be because we need to plant trees by the trillion (1,000,000,000,000). Planting one is completely insignificant.
Yes, we need to make personal changes but real changes like 
- eating much less meat (esp. red meat) and dairy
- driving much less or buying an electric car
- flying much less (only when necessary), etc
- insulating our homes properly and avoid using natural gas for heating 
- stop buying cheap crap that we throw away a month later

But even with these changes, we will be nowhere near fixing the problem without COMPLETE SYSTEM CHANGE of our energy system. Individuals have no way to make that happen other than to VOTE. Using your vote and influencing others are is as important as everything else you can do combined. If we don't get rid of the GOP completely from Congress and the Presidency in 2020 then nothing will happen until it's too late. The world we know will literally not survive another 4 years of Trump or a GOP Senate.

now, to come to an end, what is the real problem? the billions of self absorbed, others blaming idiots, or the few who act upon the actions of these idiots?
author: Mister Twister

text:
‚Äã¬†@Mister Twister¬† 1)No, I don't think the higher ups are saving money, that's why they have 
so much in material possessions.  And maybe they don't have money in our system, that would mean they would have to pay more in taxes, or even taxes.  And you're trying to convince somebody that the "distribution is off" when these people are making more money than they know what to do with.  A little off seems a little too lenient.

2)I believe the USA is a great country, and I'm proud to live here.  That being said, I don't believe politics is much more than a puppet show.  Without looking at any stats, just my observations, I would say the majority of politicians are looking to line their pockets and themselves with the right corporations in order to set themselves and their campaign contributors up.  While I don't believe any set system will work forever (capitalism has done well, but it's just the beginning.  How much credit can every industrialized country really have with each other?  That's not a house of cards being built to fall?) I also don't believe having people in government who are mostly motivated by money is a good solution.  And the job thing, while other positions in government aren't as secure as some, do you really think we're being democratic about things?  You don't think some get rigged, others outwardly over turned (like when the electoral college overturns the majority vote)?

3)I think you're being too kind with the 10%, I would go lower, but sure, if you're willing to go up to the 10% I would too.  I believe it's something like the top 1% own 90%, but you're numbers are better.  And no, I believe the population is a problem, and something else that needs to be addressed.  I don't think having a limit on children is a bad thing in theory, but being able to do that worldwide would be almost impossible with religion and personal freedom coming into play.  I don't see, however, how giving more money for people to spend on our economy would be a bad thing though.  These people would still be rich, they just wouldn't have as much.  The former Governer of Minnesota Jesse Ventura suggested not a minimum wage increase, but a maximum wage cap. That seems reasonable to me.  And going back to the companies in general, what if they didn't use materials that needed to be thrown into landfills?  Why don't all companies have biodegradable plastics?  And you seem to be confusing what I've said with socialism, or communism.  I never said that the money should be split up evenly.  If you don't work, you shouldn't get money.  However, I do believe that people in teaching, or in the healthcare field (LNA's and nurses to begin with) should see an increase in their pay.  Teachers are building the future of our children, and they are responsible for their well being.  Would you be more willing to put in your all if you were making 100k a year as opposed to 45k to deal with little kids who tell you to go f yourself and then have their parents try to threaten your job?  And an LNA has probably literally cared for a person in your family to ensure that they are taken care of.  They get 30k a year on average to care for human beings.  Meanwhile, the CEO of the company they work for (possibly got the job because of nepotism, but maybe not) gets 13 million... 13 million.  And you're trying to convince me that he shouldn't get a reusable towel program that may cost him more per year to run per year, but instead should just throw every towel away once it's used?  You're throwing a lot of black and white images out there, where I was going with more of a grey tone.  I believe it's everybody, and all people can do their part, but I do believe it starts from the top and goes down.  China is out of control with it's environmental issues, and if I'm not mistaken they're pretty much spearheaded their own problem and are one of the leading, if not the leading industrialized country in renewable energy.  I'm not even saying that it's going to change the climate, we don't know what the Earth is going to do.  I'm talking about polluting the air that children live around, I'm talking about foods being sprayed with chemical that is known to cause cancer.  Back to the house of cards reference, it's all being built on a crumbling foundation that can't sustain.  Can we fix everything?  No, but we (that's everybody, corporations down to the single parents) should strive to do something better.  I don't believe that will happen, but I have to try to stay positive.

4)I've already talked about this, but just to go point for point.  No, I never said it would be cheap.  I didn't say it would all magically get fixed, I never even think any of this will happen, I just hope that it does.  We all know for a fact that there are many ways to cheapen certain expenses.  The biggest problem with going more environmentally friendly is that it will put other companies out of business.  Would it suck for the oil companies if a big chunk of their market was hit, of course, but that doesn't mean bankruptcy is a forgone conclusion.  With how companies are mismanaged and trying to continuously up their bottom it would be hard for a lot of them (thinking back to the big bank bail outs a while back, you know, the one people paid for, and then the CEO's got record breaking bonus'?  Yeah, see, I don't think that was a good use of our money, and if banks hadn't been chasing the immediate dollar signs being waved in front of them, but had a more realistic, sustainable growth plan, then I'm thinking it could have been different).  The only thing I was really implying is that the people who make the most money should be doing their part as well.  Does it mean that they won't be able to buy 5 yachts?  Yes, yes it does.  Oh well, they'll have to deal with only have 1 or 2.  

To that end, I would say that the problem is the world in general.  Instead of using money for good, it gets used for greed way too much.  Not everyone is like this, and there are plenty of rich people who do and mean well.  Then there are companies of dodge paying taxes.  And we're not just talking a few dollars.  Imagine what could be done to the public school system (just to start with) if more money was put into it?  But instead of money being put back into the infrastructure of our country, it's in offshore accounts.  And again, I don't think I ever outwardly demonized corporations while putting the common person on a pedestal for this.  I was simply reading through the comments and saw a lot of people talking about what they and others needed to do individually, and I wanted to let like minded people know that corporations have a big part in this as well.  I don't feel like I can accurately answer your question, because I don't feel either one is an optimal choice.  My personal opinion is that people who have a lot of money tend to think about how they can spend/use that money for themselves and not the greater of humans in general.  Again, because for some reason I feel that you're the type of person to look at the one tree in the forest but not the whole forest, I don't say this about every company or wealthy person. 
  I don't think any person is an idiot for trying to make some sense of this crazy world.  That's great that you have your opinions, and you may be right about them.  I personally don't think we can really know yet, because we haven't gotten to that time yet.  In the grand scheme, we know very little about what the future is going to hold.  We can pretend that building this house of cards up will be sustainable forever, but my money would not be on that being the final outcome.  I'm not saying you're wrong, I'm just not a person who is easily convinced of things that aren't yet observable.  And when that person insults my intelligence and then goes on a tirade that is nothing more than inconclusive stat's and predictions that other people are making, I'm even less impressed.  Have a nice day!
author: ImInPhilVIlle25

text:
¬†@ImInPhilVIlle25¬† 1. Like all us citizens, you automatically assume that the US(327M people) is the centre of the world and you can use it as an example in a debate about the whole world. You do realize, that the us has more problems than other countries with a comparable economy? And the world has 7.6B people, using the us as an example might be useless when it comes to a world wide problem.

1.1 have you even considered, how they got the money? And that owning a company or investement is something entirely different than an average job? Why should they pay more, just because they have more? Same cut for everyone, or else you just force them to leave your country, or invest all their money in buildings and ressources like gold, effectively making them less rich when it comes to money, do you gain anything out of that? And again, they are just playing by the rules that the people gave them.

2. Maybe i can clear things up here. You say politicians are just stuffing their own pockets and do not really care about the people. And thats not entirely wrong, but stupid. I use your example with the electoral college, something i find stupid as hell btw, and ask you, how they got the power to overthrow the public vote? They told the right people the right things and they voted for them, so they could win the necessary states. No politician can do this on their own. And here comes the problem with the system: Democracy, like it is considered today, is damn stupid. Right now, you get peoples opinion, not the right answer. And that is, what every politician wants, they want to please their opinions, so they can get their votes. Of course they have to promise a lot, but can only do a little. People do not think about the negative impacts of the actions they demand. Our politician could do more for the environment, but the moment the prizes rise, and the taxes go up, people would complain, because when the money get's low, we tend to not give a sh** about the environment anymore. Would he get reelected? Or would people just vote for the next best idiot to promise them a better future and tax cuts? Why should our politician do something about the environment, if he just loses the next election, his job, and every achievement he got during his time in power? See where i wanna get? It's the half knowing idiots who are allowed to vote who are the problem. If the world where full of smart and educated people, no politician would need to lie. But people want things and they don't care much about the negative impacts, but they love to complain about them.
Should they have let the banks go bankrupt? Wanna bet how many homeless people they would have right now? It wasn't executed perfectly, but it wasn't as bad as everyone made it out to be.

3. Now i tell you something about big companies. Why don't they use your plastics? Because it would cost them millions. And it's not just that, because if you start with one thing, 20 others come as well, and soon you lose a lot of money. Why is that bad? i give you an example:  Let's say they(CEO's etc) get a million or two more for, let's say 4-5% increase of profit, thats a couple hundred millions for a big company. See how much the difference is? The money is used to invest and keep the company healthy, which secures peoples jobs and their future in the company. If the CEO where to go the eco friendly way, and he would lose some profit(thats what would happen), he would get fired, investors would leave and the company would have a problem, which would be bad for peoples jobs. Why the hell should he do that? It's the same system from the bottom to the top, they are just living in it, cause thats what you can do, otherwise you are screwed.
Now in regards to the mentioned income max. , you would simply take people the drive to go on, why should i increase the profit of the company, if i am already at max? Would this help anyone? Or would you exclude shareholders and investors? Cause then i would simply take my max money and do the same, and there wouldn't be much left for the bottom. Stupid idea.
And do you really think the CEO of google has the time to look into every departement and every contract to find where he can save money? It's the small people who want to get higher that find them. He is just happy to sign them, make a bit more profit and keep his job. As long as careers are a thing, and the system that enables them, this is how it goes. Problem is, there isn't a better system(i mean capitalism). 

4. I used my example to show you how much money we are talking about, and that every persons share wouldn be that much, because you would have to invest for every person on the planet. And now think if it would solve anything, if people had the mentioned amount more. They couldn get houses, not even a new car, and we should build up a new infrastructure with that small amount of money? The problem is ONLY the demand. And less children are stupid as well, because then you have rising numbers of old people and a falling numbers for young people, who produce everything. Can't really do that as well. I use so much black and white, because grey is a compromise, and we are 50 years to late for compromises. I'm just damn tired of people who argue like you, with a severe lack of basic knowledge but huge amounts of optimism. It's time to wake up an start acting RATIONALLY, not trying to shift the blame back and fourth(what you basically did, if i compare your first with the last post) or honeycoat everything and make the changes as comfortable as possible.

5. You seem to misinterpret how this universe works. If you run towords a wall and you see it, you would stop, would you? Or run around, turn etc. because you know what would happen otherwise. If i blindfold you, you can't see it so you have no means to change something in the right way. But the future is VERY clear and we can see the wall getting bigger and bigger as we come closer. I'm not a prophet, i'm someone who looks at facts and acts upon them and right now, there is not a single fact that tells us, that there is a good outcome if we don't change drastically, how we live on this planet. Except maybe, that without humans, the next generation of plants or animals(once the world has recovered) is better of without us. If you like that kind of thinking.

I did not insult you're inteligence, i called you dumb, because of your words and thoughts. There's not much information for me to judge about your intelligence, or what your brain is capable of. However, i can judge your thoughts. The way you use your intelligence. Do you think, reading a few books and getting a basic level of understanding regarding a lot of things makes me even a bit smarter than you? It's knowledge, nothing more, but i can judge better because i have it. That's what i am acusing you of: knowing not enough to talk about the things you do, thats why i wrote dumb and stupid. And i'm rude, because you and the people who think and act like you, are the main reason we got here. Instead of just acknowleding the problem, studying it and finding a solution, people act upon a lack of knowledge, mixed with a good amount of optimism or any other ideology and produce nothing but crap. That's of course not your fault alone, but it is tiresome, to have the same conversation again and again, proofing people wrong again and again and then go back and start from zero, because there are just too many of them. It is my way of trying to change something, by getting people to realize the stupidity of their thoughts fueled by group mentality and moronic ethnical standarts, because at the end of the day, only rational thinking can get you anywhere, but i'm not going anywhere, it seems.

edit: i'm not against optimism per se, but you have to do everything you can and then hope for the best, not do what you think is enough and then hope that you are right

Of course we all should know this by now, and most people should understand that while yes, it's up to them as well, that if companies hadn't looked to MAXIMIZE their profits (not saying it's not smart business to maximize profits, but when it starts coming at the expense of the human race as a whole, that should be a red flag), then we wouldn't have to "recycle" so much plastic (the reason why I put recycle in quotations is because most of the stuff we recycle just ends up in landfills anyways, so what is the average person supposed to do, make their own multi million dollar recycling center).

¬†@Mister Twister¬†Lol, wow.  I didn't even read what you wrote.  I'm just going to leave you with a classic:

"Let It Go"
(from "Frozen" soundtrack)

The snow glows white on the mountain tonight
Not a footprint to be seen
A kingdom of isolation
And it looks like I'm the queen

The wind is howling like this swirling storm inside
Couldn't keep it in, heaven knows I tried!

Don't let them in, don't let them see
Be the good girl you always have to be
Conceal, don't feel, don't let them know
Well, now they know!

Let it go, let it go
Can't hold it back anymore
Let it go, let it go
Turn away and slam the door!

I don't care
What they're going to say
Let the storm rage on
The cold never bothered me anyway!

It's funny how some distance
Makes everything seem small
And the fears that once controlled me
Can't get to me at all!

It's time to see what I can do
To test the limits and break through
No right, no wrong, no rules for me I'm free!

Let it go, let it go
I am one with the wind and sky
Let it go, let it go
You'll never see me cry!

Here I stand
And here I'll stay
Let the storm rage on!

My power flurries through the air into the ground
My soul is spiraling in frozen fractals all around
And one thought crystallizes like an icy blast
I'm never going back
The past is in the past!

Let it go, let it go
And I'll rise like the break of dawn
Let it go, let it go
That perfect girl is gone!

Here I stand
In the light of day
Let the storm rage on

The cold never bothered me anyway!


With best regards,


The Girl from "Frozen"

text:
That's simply not true. 
SOME individuals are doing a lot, some are doing a bit, and the VAST majority does nothing. 

For example, when asked where they buy meat, over 50% of people say they only buy high quality, expensive, harshly checked, ecologically concious meat, and only 1-3 times a week, and so on.
Yet the actual sales numbers show that only about 4% of sold meat is that kind and everyone else is a lying liar from Liarsville. 
And don't get me started on vegans who hold that label up like they alone are saving the world, while also requiring their daily avocado toast despite avocados being a complete nightmare for the climate, or eat tofu as a meat replacement that the rain forest is getting chopped down for.
Americans come to my country and whine about the small selection in supermarkets because oh god how could you survive without 2080 different brands of cereals like you have at home, but that also means INSANE amounts of food get thrown away because it was just produced to "have more options" in the supermarket and so on.
And don't even get me started on the topics of personal cars and the massive amount of online orders that people place for convenience sake...

Baseline is, very few are willing to actually start with themselves and really change how they live life. Big companies won't change if we don't change first.

If we want to eat meat 7 days a week, that has to come from somewhere, and companies will fill that market. 
If we want big cars that go 400km/h and can drive cross-continent without stopping, car companies are gonna continue treating hydrogen fuel cell cars and electric cars as "special" models and not the norm because those cars can't do that. 
As long as we take a plane over a train ticket for short distances because "2 hours including check-in is so much less annoying than a 6 hour train ride, see how much time I save..!", companies have no reason to build more train tracks or put money into researching ways to have faster train travel so you can be more flexible and faster on the ground. 
As long as we decide to order a single pencil off amazon instead of picking one up in the shop the next time we go, some postal company will drive a delivery truck all the way to your doorstep for that single pencil, because you asked for it. 
If we always switch to the cheapest electricity supplier regardless of how they create said electricity, there is no incentive for suppliers to use only renewable, possibly more expensive sources. And so on and so on.

Companies change because our needs change, no other reasons. If our needs haven't changed, we can't blame the companies for still fulfilling them.

¬†@SleepySera¬† Its so troubling to see so many people on here so sadly mistaken. Companies didn't arise from a need, they arised because of the power of advertising, because of profit. I.e ''present shiny thing to people, people will want'' even if BEFORE said shiny thing, noone needed it, noone even knew of it. 

Humans have ALWAYS had a source for food, materials to make a living and so forth. Until the industrial age came along and put a price tag on EVERYTHING, advertised things we never saw before, things we never needed before. And if you reject that, you reject society, and since industrialism, society is built on capitalism from the ground up. If everyone shift their focus on veganism, can you really trust that a company is actually getting their vegan products in an environmentally and humane way? LOL no, blind faith like that doesn't work under capitalism. You HAVE to create regulations, YOU HAVE TO monitor companies and prevent them from doing practices that harm our planet. And you even have to straight up ban certain products, ban expansions and absolutely fucking ban practices that make the industry a monopoly. Same company that sell you your fancy vegan eco friendly salad can be selling a shit ton of meat under the guise of another name and you would be supporting them too, thats how monopoly works. Thats how most brands in America work. You gotta change yourself of course, but theres ALWAYS gonna be those that don't , you can't be a fucking jehovas witness and try to convert them, you gotta vote for people that FORCE companies to change. You gotta vote for people that STRENGTHEN small businesses, so that society changes DESPITE some people that refuse to change their diet or consumption habits. This problem started with capitalism and its gonna fucking end when we end capitalism.
